displaydate: 1849 (stone); late 19th to first half of 20th century (rubbing)
medium: Hanging scroll; ink rubbing on paper
markings:
Rubbing seals:
Gaozong 高宗, Southern Song emperor (1107-1187, r. 1127-1162) 
	“Deshoudian bao” 德壽殿寶, sq. relief
Unknown
	“[]” , squarish relief

Collector seal:
Unknown
	sq. relief (left bottom corner)
inscribed:
Left:
Su Shi 蘇軾 (1036-1101)
紹聖二年[1095]四月佛壽日蘇軾寫
Rubbing seal: “Su Shi jushi” 蘇軾居士, sq. intaglio

Right:
Jiang Guolin 江國霖 (1811-1859)
戊申[1848]之春舟過黃州李石荺司馬見贈此幅，
盖徐蓉舫太守刻於赤壁者。及至惠陽登合
江樓覽先生坆居無獨先生手蹟。同摹勒入石
以光[]宇時道光己酉[1849]重九蜀東江國霖識。
Notes: 
1. Huangzhou 黃州 county, Hubei province; site of the historical naval battle at the Red Cliff (Chibi 赤壁) at the end of the Han dynasty. Su Shi wrote the “Former” and “Latter Ode on the Red Cliffs” (前,後赤壁赋).
2. Li Shiyun 李石荺 (late Qing dynasty)
3. Xu Rongfang 徐蓉舫 (late Qing dynasty)
4. Hejiang Lou 合江樓 tower, in present-day Huizhou惠州, Guangdong province. In the Song dynasty, when Su Shi was demoted and exiled in 1094 to Huiyang 惠陽 in Guangdong, by rights he should not have been permitted inside, but because of the official Zhan Fan’s 詹范high regard for Su Shi, he was given permission. 
Summary:
In a boat trip in 1848, Jiang Guolin visited Li Shiyun, the sima official of Huangzhou, who gave him this rubbing, which Prefect Xu Rongfang had carved at the Red Cliff. Up until then, nothing in Su Shi’s hand survived from the time he lived in exile at the Hejiang Lou in Huiyang. Carved into stone ...on the 9th day of the 9th month of 1849. Recorded by Jiang Guolin. [Su Shi’s second period of exile started in 1094, and the rubbing has a Su Shi inscription dated to 1095].

makers.displaymaker: Su Shi 蘇軾, painter, attributed to, 1036–1101

texts.textentryhtml: Representation of God of Longevity (Shouxing 壽星) as a stout, bearded old man with a high brow. His robes are outlined in broad graphic lines in contrast the fine lines used for his facial features. The pictorial stone this rubbing was taken from was engraved in 1849 after an earlier engraving carved at the Red Cliff in Huangzhou county, Hubei province, that purportedly follows a Song dynasty model with a 1095 inscription signed Su Shi.

bibliography.boilertext: "Recent Acquisitions," Record of the Art Museum, Princeton University 18, no. 1 (1959): p. 40-42.
